David Drayton.Action: Leads family safely downstairs carrying candles in the dark, showing care and bravery especially for his son Billy.
Scowls at the damage to his house and painting, showing frustration but also responsibility.
Carefully leads his family downstairs carrying a candle during a storm, showing calmness and responsibility.
Stops and assesses damage outside in daylight, shows awareness of surroundings and situation.
Prompted Steff to make a list of concerns like food spoilage, indicating practical thinking.
Takes initiative to get supplies to repair damage and protect the house.
Comforts Steff by downplaying the loss of the painting and emphasizing their safety.
Shows regret and self-blame for not bringing the painting downstairs.
Shares a light moment of humor with Steff despite the crisis.
Plans to go into town before the store is bought out, showing foresight and planning.
Acknowledges he cannot save the painting and intends to start over, showing realistic assessment of the situation.
Decides to call the studio to extend deadline, demonstrating resourcefulness and communication skills.
Expresses regret for not bringing the painting downstairs, showing self-critical but realistic evaluation.
Plans to get plastic sheeting and duct tape to seal the broken window before dark, showing practical problem-solving.
Focuses on what truly matters ('Just stuff, hon. We're all right'), showing emotional intelligence but not directly competence-related.
Smiles and gently takes Steff's hand, light teasing about 'low standards'
Responds patiently to Steff's concerns about the mist and tries to reassure her

Waves back at Steff, putting his misgivings aside to drive out with others.

Engages in casual, lighthearted conversation with Norton and Billy during the drive.
Shrugs and allows Norton to use the radio without complaint.
Uses the dismissive term 'Miss Tabloid' referring to Edna's stories.

Observes power company trucks going the other way and deduces power may be restored, showing practical reasoning.
Allows Norton to operate the radio without objection, demonstrating flexibility and trust but also lacking control over his environment.
Engages in light conversation about the storm and military activity, maintaining composure and social interaction under uncertain circumstances.
Engages respectfully with his son Billy by asking him to respond to Mrs. Carmody's claims, showing trust and encouraging Billy to speak up.
Describes Mrs. Carmody's rant seriously but without openly mocking or dismissing her in front of his son, demonstrating tolerance.

Allows others (Norton, Billy) to take initiative in some interactions rather than taking dominant control.

Navigates the market during a blackout calmly, noticing details such as store staff shortages and manual operations, indicating situational awareness.

Interacts calmly and supportively with Ollie amidst a tense atmosphere.
Takes Steff's shopping list and suggests meeting at checkout, demonstrating effective coordination.
Responds cautiously and honestly to Billy about social relationships, reflecting thoughtful communication.

Engages in casual interaction with community members like acknowledging Mrs. Reppler and noticing soldiers, maintaining a calm presence.
Grabs items needed and efficiently organizes them by tossing to Billy to place in the cart, facilitating faster shopping.
Responds to Billy's comment about not being mad by saying 'That's a start,' showing measured optimism and realistic appraisal rather than naive confidence.

Silently observes tense situation and people around without intervening.
Observes surroundings attentively, notices details such as the MPs arrival, people’s reactions, and interactions around him.

Holds his son Billy close when the situation becomes frightening.

Leans on the horn repeatedly to get attention at his home, indicates concern and attempt to reach out.
Silently endures the shock of seeing his wife's hat and her dead foot in the mist, showing restrained emotional response.

Leans on the horn repeatedly to get attention at his broken-into house, shows awareness by noticing details like broken window and personal items, then decisively turns the vehicle around to leave after confirming the grim reality.
No indication of panic; maintains composure despite emotional shock of seeing his wife's hat and dead foot, proceeds to drive carefully through hazardous terrain.
Picks up the gun and counts remaining bullets, acknowledges dire situation, tries to reassure others by saying 'I'll figure something out.'
Fires four gunshots for the group, sparing his son, showing protectiveness and sacrifice.
Breaks down emotionally afterwards, crying openly, showing sincere grief and vulnerability.
Attempts suicide but ultimately does not follow through, suggesting some internal restraint or hope.
Attempts to take responsibility by acknowledging limited resources and assuring others he will figure something out despite dire circumstances.
Uses remaining bullets thoughtfully, understanding the dire implications of limited ammo and number of people.
Struggles with despair and grief openly and intensely after traumatic events, showing emotional vulnerability but impaired mental state.
Does not follow through with suicide despite extreme anguish, indicating inner strength and ability to hold on in face of overwhelming hopelessness.
Clutches the roof of the Scout and screams uncontrollably despite help being nearby.
Takes deep breaths and steels himself before facing the unknown outside the Scout.
Waits patiently and listens carefully to sounds in the mist, demonstrating alertness and situational awareness.
Does not respond to the arriving soldiers, becomes overwhelmed and succumbs to uncontrollable screaming.
